text: JUSTIN NORTON: All right.

Welcome to our
first conversation.

Our water cooler conversations
in healthcare AI.

We're doing this from the
perspective of two Stanford

faculty members,
physicians who are trying

to find our way for what's
happening next in healthcare

and how AI is going
to change the field.

Matt's the Chief
Scientific Officer

for Microsoft in Healthcare, in
addition to his Stanford faculty
role.

And I'm Justin Norton,
CEO and founder

of a company called
Qualified Health,

and also we teach together
a course on generative AI
in medicine at Stanford.

The purpose of this
discussion here

is these are conversations we've
had for the past years trying

to figure out
what's coming next,

and especially with the pace of
development, what's happening

in the field, the news
and articles and research
is changing by the week.

And when we were
asked by Stanford

to put this together a
little bit more broadly,

we said, OK, we'll
record ourselves having

these conversations and bring
some of our best friends
and people across the space.

And so today, to kick off
our inaugural episode,

we'll have Troy Tazbaz,
who recently was a leading
digital health for the FDA.

So we're going to cover a
handful of current topics.
We'll pull up some data.

We'll see where the
conversation goes.

And as a note,
these conversations

are our personal
opinions and do not

reflect the opinions
of Stanford or any

of our companies
or organizations
that we're a part of.

So to kick things off, we
wanted to start with like,

where are we at now in the
healthcare AI landscape?

And I want to pull up one
chart and then, Matt, I'll

turn to you to kind
of explain what

we're looking at
a little bit here

on what's coming next
on what we see right now

for effects of using these
tools since the launch,

and kind of where people
are getting some gains.

MATTHEW LUNGREN:
Yeah, absolutely.

I mean, this is a great paper
just from the past week.

And really starts to
show, despite those of us

who've been tracking this very
closely for, at least, a couple

of years, as generative AI
started to permeate through kind

of just the general
workforce, we always

knew that people were
kind of using the models.
I think we saw a lot of usage.

I think people would talk
about it, but they wouldn't--

maybe they wouldn't even
surface that they were using it.

I think Ethan Malik had
that great blog talking
about the secret cyborg.

People were getting
some work done,

but they weren't
asking for more work

so that was kind
of a phenomenon.
But this has been--

this is maybe one of the
best recent papers kind

of looking at, OK, let's
actually break down

all the different knowledge
work tasks and actually see

what the difference
is leveraging the best

new model to
complete their tasks

and how much time
they're saving.

And I mean, the
takeaway here again,

I think with some of the caveats
that this is very specifically

designed to look for this,
but tripling productivity

for knowledge work
tasks across the economy

is a pretty eye
popping result to me.

And I think the other
thing that I took away

from this was how many
people were using it

and really have only come
around to using it in maybe
in the last six months.

And I sort of feel like, of
course everyone's using it,
right?

But I think it's still kind
of slowly making its way.

And then, of course,
brings me to healthcare.

And thinking about maybe just
the only study I've seen,

which is the British
Medical Journal

study that talked about
the GPs that they surveyed.

How many are using
it in their practice?

So I think it raises a lot
of interesting questions,

but it's definitely starting
to paint this pattern

that as the tools get better,
people are adopting them

and absolutely
saving time no matter
what they do for a living.

JUSTIN NORTON: Yeah,
and just for everyone,

the GP study from the
British medical journal

showed I think it was
last year, 20% of GPs

are using these tools on
a at least weekly basis
and for clinical care.

Not just in general or, you
know, writing emails, et cetera,
which is pretty astounding.

And I'll pull up one more
thing and then try one and see

what you hear on
this, but what's

fascinating is that's
the backdrop of what's
happening generally in AI.
This was a study done by Hims.

They released end of
December just a survey.

And most people or
most medical workplaces

don't have access to these
chatbots or any training
related to AI.

Many of them are restricted
from using AI at work.

And so it's this
weird moment in time

where at least many people
are using these tools at work.

At least in
healthcare, many people

aren't supposed to be
using these tools at work

or don't have access
to these tools.

And so I had a
funny conversation

with a head of a health
care organization

to remain nameless
was like, hey,

do people have access
to tools like ChatGPT?

And I was like,
oh, yeah, everyone

has their phone, which
hopefully doesn't scare Troy

too much as a regulator and
worried about HIPAA and data
violations and things.

TROY TAZBAZ: I'm no
longer a regulator, so--
use it with what you want.
Yeah.

MATTHEW LUNGREN: What do you
what do you make of this, Troy?

How do we put these
pieces together?

TROY TAZBAZ: This
is an interesting
between the two charts.

And in my previous role
before going to the government

and then now back
to a similar role,

we used to do this
study to ensure

that our development investments
were appropriately prioritized.

And one thing that
we looked at was

like IT spend as a percentage
of the revenue of an industry.

And one thing that
was quite evident

is that healthcare tends to
be on the lower end of that,

and which means that when it
comes to technology, technology

investments,
technology adoption,

it trails some of the other
industries that go on.

So, frankly, I think this
maybe speaks to that.

And the question now
becomes, is the lack of use

because there's just not
enough maybe approved

technology available
in healthcare?

Or is it more of a
systematic problem

around whether we're teaching
this stuff in medical school?

As two people who both
gone through medical school

but also teach at
a medical school,

one fundamental truth exists,
which is it's still new.

Being a medical professional
is a knowledge worker,

it's all about the
knowledge, and so I

think that maybe
perhaps tradition

is playing into also some
of this lack of adoption.

So I think it's always going
to be fundamentally probably

two prongs, which is are
the tools really available
and are they healthcare centric?

And second of all, are
we actually ensuring

that the next generation medical
professionals are coming up
with--

you they have an
understanding of how

to use these tools in their day
to day process of delivering
care?

JUSTIN NORTON:
Yeah, and I think--

MATTHEW LUNGREN: Let
me interject there,

because I fundamentally
agree that I think

at the top down approach
that we typically take

to health enterprise software
training, ensuring ROI,
all those things come into play.

I feel like we're seeing
a bottoms up, though,
don't you agree?
Everyone's got a phone.

Everyone's using it most
likely in their day to day,
and those that are sort of--

those have used it and
experimented with it maybe even

six months ago, a year
ago, may have dismissed it

because of a flaw,
or a hallucination,
or whatever the issue was.

And maybe they haven't
been keeping pace
with what's actually changing.

And because it is so fast, it's
more like a river than a lake
to me.

And every time you look
at it, it's different,

and those that aren't
really keeping up

aren't really getting
that those, those turns

at bat to get the experience
to be able to leverage it more.
I struggle with this.

Because there are institutions
like Stanford and UCSF

and others out there that
have set up enterprise,

HIPAA compliant
instances of these models

for their workforce to allow
them to start to explore
and in a very bottoms up way.

But at the end of
the day, I struggle

with trying to how does
this fit into the sort

of traditional healthcare SAAS
box for all the different use
cases, it's powerful for?
I don't know.

I don't have an answer,
but it's part of me

feels like the pragmatist, or
the realist, or the fatalist

in me, whatever, sort of
feels like they're just

going to find a way to use
it if you aren't able to make
it available to everyone.
Do you know what I mean?

JUSTIN NORTON: I mean,
and the reason in my head

is like these tools, this
is the ChatGPT, right?

And actually there's
an interesting graph

that we can pull up later
of like different usage

from the same study
we just looked at.

This is the fastest growing
consumer piece of technology

ever, and this is
marketed to consumers.
They're pushing.

There's all these companies
competing pushing the pace,

and it's so good that it's
coming in a bottoms-up way
to healthcare.

We saw this before
in healthcare.

We saw this with social
networks and people

figuring out like posting
healthcare information

and institutions freaked out as
people are posting informations
and pictures on social media.

So we've had a few
like early starts

of seeing technology
seep in consumer first

into healthcare institutions,
and this is just
the next iteration of that.

I think what's
potentially different is

the speed at which
it's happening

and the utility, at
least, from that.

Candidly, I don't believe
all those 3x graphs.

That's a little bit
too bright for me.

I get improvements,
yeah, but it's useful.

TROY TAZBAZ: Here's what
I'll also say about, I think,
this technology in general.

About the whole bottoms up
versus tops down type of thing,
right?

I mean, if you look at what
happened with generative AI,

I mean, particularly
once ChatGPT 4 came out

is that, they go, OK, here's
this great new capability.
Where could we apply it to?

That's a very bottoms
up approach kind

of technological
adoption strategy.

It wasn't like, hey,
here are the problems

that we're trying to solve for
whatever the industry might be.

And here are the
tools available,

and generative AI just happens
to be yet another tool for that.

And so I think by just the how
the technology was integrated

into society or how it's being
integrated in the society
was very bottoms up.

The other thing that I'll
also say, and you two

know this a whole
lot more than I do,

but healthcare system,
especially in the United States,
is a highly fragmented anyway.

I mean, and so which means that
any change, any improvements,

any progress really gets
done from a bottoms as well.

And so when I was kind of
wearing a regulators hat,

I always kind of used to work
with all the hospital systems

and say, instead of have
the technological providers,

technology providers
come to you and say,

here's what we'd like
you to integrate.

Why are you not all coming
together and say, these

are all the problems
that we're all

trying to address that are
consistent across whether it's

a large hospital system, an
AMC, or a community center?

And I think that
type of you have

to flip the switch
a little bit and say

that the hospital systems
and the healthcare, I guess,

ecosystem has to be essentially
providing the demand signal

to say, hey, technology
providers, these are the issues

that we need to address in the
priority we need to address them
in.

MATTHEW LUNGREN: I
really like that comment

because that I think is
what we're starting to see.
I think they're--

I don't know if we have
the paper, Justin or not,

but we can maybe
put it in the notes.

But some institutions
have said now

that we've implemented this
sort of HIPAA compliant way

to leverage the models
for whatever use case

across the enterprise,
now we can actually

look at a bird's eye
view and say, well,
what are they using it for?
And who's using it for what?

And then that really does
start to your point get--

boil down the things
that it's actually

having an impact for
at a very organic way.

And they allow them
say, well, do I
want to operationalize that?

Or do I want to look
for a vendor for that?

Or do I just want to have
folks share best practices

and their prompts
and maybe even have

like sort of prompt
workflows already baked in?

I mean, I really feel like this
is still a very early days.

And the part that I
struggle with still, though,

is that we kind of
make decisions around

where the capabilities are
with a snapshot in time again.

But I feel like
it's like, again,

taking a picture of
a movie or something.

It's like you're
going to look again,

it's going to be totally
different thing going on,

and it's going to be like, oh,
does that change everything?

And that makes it
so challenging.
It's a moving target.

JUSTIN NORTON: You got
to talk about this then,

at least, on the performance
curve that you're talking about.

MATTHEW LUNGREN: I mean
this is just one of many.

And I'm sure folks
in the audience

have seen a ton of these, and
there's literally several dozen.

So there's benchmarks that
folks have for a long time

felt are going to be very,
very difficult for models.

And as soon as you
hear someone say,

I've created a new
benchmark, it's

going to be years
before AI solves it.

And then without question
3 or 4 months later,

you'll see one of these
exponential curve graphs.

And I think, if
I'm being honest,

I think over the course of maybe
the last 4 or 5 months since we

really kind of started to
understand test time, compute,

inference, scaling on
essentially letting the model

"think," quote-unquote, there
really doesn't seem to be a lot

of benchmarks left that we
aren't saturating to the point

where any further reference to
them is almost not very useful.

I still feel, and this is
especially true in medicine,

that there's a there's a
disconnect between some

of the benchmark that at
least we use for healthcare.

Broadly, GPQA is obviously
one, and actually

the performance on specific
real good use cases
that will actually drive impact.

But nonetheless, to me
it still is a signal,

I think, and maybe
a call to action.

Because what I
would like to see--
and, again, I love the GPQA.
I love the SWA Bench Verified.
I love all these benchmarks.

Where are our
benchmarks in healthcare

of similar things for
tasks that we actually

really do think are hard to
solve, but are really important.

And then I would love to see
a bunch of these curves doing
that for those too.
You know what I mean?

And that's the one
thing I sort of I'm

a little jealous if
I'm being honest.
I kind of look at these.

I mean, man coders,
they're killing it.
It's like, what do they say now?

Sam recently said, what 03
is amongst the top, whatever,

150 coders in the world
or something like that.

I would love to
have a model that

is top physician in whatever
specialty with a really good
benchmark to prove that out.

JUSTIN NORTON: Well, people are
trying to talk about this with

01 and case management tasks for
things like this where it keeps
getting better and better.

And Jonathan Chen, one
of our Stanford faculty,

has been putting out paper
after paper of, hey, actually,

we all thought AI plus
humans would be better
than just AI or humans.

And actually, we're finding
at least on the benchmarks

currently that
we're talking about

and testing against
AI on its own

is doing better without human
and physician interaction.

And so how do we how do
we make sense of that?
Are the benchmarks correct?
Or are they right?

I guess the flip side of
that is do we even need
those benchmarks anymore, Matt?
AI is winning.

MATTHEW LUNGREN:
It's very hard for me

to wrap my head around
this because, I've
been doing health AI, right?
Building models for like what?

Over 10 years of all
different shapes and sizes.

And every time I'm on a panel
or I'm talking to a class,

it's always like
AI plus human is

going to be better
than human or AI alone.

It's actually like it's
ingrained into me that

mentality, and yet I cannot find
a really well done study that
shows that right.

Instead, I see studies like
the one you're showing here,

which is that these models
do really well on their own,

and they do better on their own
than physicians using the model.
Now, I don't know.

I'm sure there's some aspect
of human computer interaction.

There's some aspect of
the benchmark itself,

and there's probably
an aspect of just
like learning the familiarity.

I think all of us
know it takes a while

to start to understand how to
use these models effectively,
et cetera.

But it still doesn't
change the fact to me

here, where I'm begging the
community to prove me right.

Otherwise I have to go back and
correct so many statements where

I was convinced that AI plus
physicians was going to be
better than either one alone.
I don't know.

I mean, Troy, I don't know
if you have a take on this.

JUSTIN NORTON: And I want to
know your regulatory take too,
or how worried?

We've always been
in that paradigm,

but then we're kind of
seeing data differently.
How are you thinking about this?

TROY TAZBAZ: Well, I think
it's really hard to determine
what is it better at?

I mean, kind of looking
at this particular chart

and then having
this conversation,

it's like is it better
at just being a physician

or is it very,
very specific tasks
that it does actually better?

So I think without that
context it's kind of hard.

And I think these are
also, in my opinion,

I don't want to say they're
dangerous, but it's more of a--
it's missing the point.
I mean, the point is that--

and I've said this before
and we've talked about this

before, it's like
if you start kind

of pitting AI against, let's
say, some sort of a field,

and in this case it's
medical professionals, what

do you think of the adoption
curve is going to be?

And maybe that's why the
previous chart actually
says what it says.

And so I think the
question or the dialogue

should really be is that,
where can we apply this,

that it's going to perform
better than a human

and for various reasons where
the human can then focus
on the things that AI can't do?

Or it could solve for the
huge labor shortage problem.

It's like, I think
that the narrative,

when I see these types
of studies, to me,
it's very academic.

It's not, in my
opinion, real in a sense

that it's not
solving the problem.
Sure.

It's the analogy that
I use often where it's

like you could put a Ferrari
on rush hour traffic on 101,

and is it going to perform
better than something else?

No, probably you're going to
get from point A to point B

at the exact same time, but you
just spent another $270,000 more
getting there.

And so I think the
narrative needs

to change that we need to
stop comparing the two.

We need to say that
where is it applicable?

Where can we apply
it to that is going

to be beneficial for both
the people who are working

in the healthcare field,
but also the patients, which
is the ultimate goal here?

And I think that's why most
medical professionals got

into the profession
to begin with.

From a regulation,
well, I actually

would love to hear
from your point of view

because both of
you are physicians.

One of you really are
practicing, and so exactly.

And so the question for
you all is like, how do you
feel about this stuff?

JUSTIN NORTON: Well,
I'll give you--
MATTHEW LUNGREN: You go first.

JUSTIN NORTON: I'll give
you a real position.

I'll give a comment
from a medical student.

TROY TAZBAZ: Real physician
versus a class together.

JUSTIN NORTON: No,
which was, hey, you

just asked this very
simple question of like,

Professor Norton,
historically, doctors

had all this knowledge that
were unique in their head,

and we would have
this conversation

and build that trust

in their action.

It's like watching

Our patients are going
to come in knowing more,

because they spent
two hours going

through every part

What is our role?

And so like just like those
questions as you start

to answer, at least for

answering tasks like
the AI is better today.

But then it's like, what
is that role question?

And that's where
I'll tie you up,

Matt, with how you
want to take that now
as you're practicing today.

MATTHEW LUNGREN: I mean, so I
live in kind of two-- it's like,

yes, I still walk by
a fax machine at work.

I still sometimes
pause and reflect

on what I actually
do in a clinical day,

and I think about what I
used to do when I started

and how different it looks in
terms of the number of things

that every couple
of years there's

a new thing, or a new form,
or a new process, or whatever.

And it's just like, we've got
this huge, multi-layered onion

that we have to peel back to
sort of stop the bleeding,

I think, in the
health care workforce.

And so to Troy's point,
yeah, the benchmarks

are telling one story, but
the reality on the ground

is, I will take anything
that will help me peel back

that onion and get me back
to taking care of patients

the way I want, the way I
was trained to do, the way I

the reason I went
into healthcare.

And I think, we've
seen some of that.

There's some solutions
that are purpose

built for a-- to
solve a problem,

and it doesn't
lead with quote AI.

The ambient nodes I
think is a great example.

There's a bunch
of these out there

and they're changing
the game, I think.

I mean, I think they're having
a real impact partially.

And, again, it sounds
like a simple solution,
but it's a real problem.

I mean, how much
time folks spend

on administrative note taking
and there's so many more,

I think, that are
low hanging fruit.

On the other hand, when
I see these kinds of--

to Justin's point that a
patient can spend a couple

hours with the
model and in theory,

again, ignoring some of
the challenges there,

walk away with a pretty good
download of the concepts

and principles of their disease
or whatever their condition is.

I mean, that to me to take
your analogy, Troy of a Ferrari
on a freeway.

Now I'm looking at is that
actually not a Ferrari,
but maybe it's a helicopter?

And the way that we're
implementing it is we're

trying to take it down the
freeway as if it's a car,

but maybe this is just a
fundamentally different

technology that does
have the opportunity
to fly to our destination.

But we don't have the
language, the ability,

the infrastructure necessarily
to take advantage of it.

I just don't know
yet, I feel like.

So I kind of live in
both worlds a little bit.

I see this huge
opportunity acceleration,

but I also see that we just
have real simple and burning
problems to solve now.

TROY TAZBAZ: Yeah, but
here's the thing though.

You're actually now
talking about the concept

of completely reimagining
this, the healthcare delivery.

Does it have to be the
way it is right now?
It's very episodic in many ways.

I mean, you get
sick and you go in

and see some sort of a
medical professional.

And I've always said
this in the past,

it's like we don't have a
healthcare system in the United
States.
We have a sick care system.

Healthcare is really when
you're engaging with your health
when you're still healthy.

And so, but so it could do
a variety of things, right?

I mean, in just
effectively self-agency

as you when you are
navigating through sick care
is definitely one of them.

And I have obviously a personal
experience in that one.

And I used to remember
saying that like, here I was,

I kind of dealt with
complex problems

at that point in
corporate world.

I managed very high
performing individuals.

And I remember going
like, how does someone

who doesn't have
my skill set ever

navigate through that system
without having any knowledge,
deep knowledge about this stuff?

And so maybe in that sense it's
going to be fantastic, right?

It's going to provide agency
to a patient, or a caregiver

as they're navigating through
that system and the problems

that come along with
navigating chronic conditions.

JUSTIN NORTON: And I know we
only have a few more minutes

together, but how do we
kind of contrast that, Troy,

and that potential you're
talking about with how that

fits in a regulatory
framework and software
as a medical device?

I know you're not
there anymore, but how

do we even start wrapping our
heads around how we would get

that helicopter different
path with healthcare

with current
regulatory paradigms?

TROY TAZBAZ: Well, I think
you have to, in my opinion,
look at this end to end thing.

I mean, I always kind of looked
at healthcare as a value chain

from that starts
with maybe you can

look at different starting
points: medical school, drug

development, medical
device development, and all
through that.

And regulation, in my
opinion, is just one part

of a critical milestone
of bringing healthcare
to the market itself.

And so when I went
into the government

and my perspective of
regulation were really just

I kind of said it's just a
fancy way of saying guardrails.

It's a parameters
where innovation

needs to happen
within, and there's not

a single other industry that
doesn't have those parameters.

And sometimes those parameters
are driven by laws of physics,

and other times they're
driven by something else.

I mean, just like we have safety
parameters when we're driving,

or aviation, or
whatever that may be.

And so regulation,
in my opinion,

should always kind
of look at this thing

and say, OK, what are the
safety parameters that you have

to establish in order to
make sure that you're taking

advantage of all of this
innovation that is happening,

but you're also reducing
the risk of that?

And so regulation shouldn't
just be done or be
considered by the government.

The government's angle is about
coming up with regulation,

but it has to work with
the industry to say,

what are the common
sense kind of guardrails
that you have to establish?

So, when I was working
in the government, that's

the tack that I took to say
that, anything that we do here

has to be effectively
implementable
by the industry itself.

Because if it can't
be implemented,

it's just a piece of
paper at that point.

And so, we looked at--
we focused on things
like lifecycle management.

Make sure that you
truly understand

how these things are not just
developed, but integrated
into healthcare system.

How it's being
the value is being

delivered, whether it's
a standalone product,

or maybe through
something like an EHR.

And then how do you
monitor this thing?

And so the biggest
thing about generative
is that it continuously adapts.
